html:

Spotify Takes Over Podcasting

Nick Hilton
Feb 8

I have a friend who refers to the sort of casually ill-informed yet self-aggrandising statement that people make (“I just can’t see house prices rising in this economy…”) as a ‘from-the-office-of’ message. In that spirit, this is my from-the-office-of message on Spotify’s acquisition of Gimlet and Anchor.

So, Spotify have bought Gimlet for c.$230m dollars. The Gimlet phenomenon rather passed me by, being a Brit who predominantly listens to British podcasts, but, as a company, it’s only 5 years old and its most successful podcasts are things like Crimetown and Reply All. It raised $15m in 2017, which, as a content creation business (especially in the podcasting sector), is a heck of an achievement.

Anchor, meanwhile, is even more of a mystery to me. It’s a tool that allows people to either host their podcasts on it completely normally, or use it as quite a rudimentary editing package. Crucially, their hosting is completely free (there is a fascinating Medium post by founder Nir Zicherman where he observes that hosting your show costs them less than 10 cents a month; which really begs the question of how so many hosts are getting themselves into financial crises…) however they do retain a more involved stake in the product. But the free hosting is hella seductive, especially given the absence of competitors in this area, and it is said that 40% of new podcasts are distributed via Anchor.

The dual acquisition is interesting because it points in two different directions. On the one hand you have the very steep pricing of prestige content at Gimlet. Gimlet will always be seen, especially amongst US influenced podcasters, as the company that brought for-profit podcasting to the mainstream. They don’t have a huge amount of infrastructure and are only running 13 shows at the moment (pricing each of those feeds at around $17m), but they are serious players. And now Spotify Originals will be serious players.

On the other hand, the Anchor acquisition looks towards the pluralism that is a huge part of podcasting. It is the most mass market podcasting business to emerge in recent years, and given the way in which it distributes advertising revenue and retains rights to programmes, it is also the most actively directed at hobbyist or on-the-side podcasters. They have tried to be clear that they don’t “own your podcast”, but the fact remains that each podcast advertises Anchor and many podcasts are registered to Spotify/Apple Podcasts by Anchor rather than the creator (though this is optional, it is a method that many new podcasters will default to). I think Anchor is a good business model and great for the ever expanding podcasting world (though I’m not sure how great the every expanding podcast world is for the ever expanding podcast world, but that’s another blog…), but it is sort of the populist twin of Gimlet, an implausible bedfellow.

So what does this all mean? There was a really good thread by ex-Gimlet guy Nathan Baschez doing the rounds on Twitter (he now works for Substack who just — with all the timing of a concussed symbols player — announced an interesting subscription based model for podcasts) which basically said the Anchor acquisition is about advertising, the Gimlet acquisition is about advertising, and, oh no, the rich get richer while the poor get podcasts.

I think it’s telling that Spotify want to create a sort-of closed-circuit system for all audio content. Podcasters tend to be much less technically minded than, say, DJs or musicians (they are generally, after all, journalists rather than audio technicians) and so bringing the podcast creation process into the same app as the distribution and sales means that creators will be very reliant on Spotify. The Anchor technology will make interaction between podcasts, and also interaction between podcasts and advertisers, much more seamless and reactive. They will also have Big Data on their side, for the first time. Because Apple, the only guys with the Big Data at the moment, have decided to sit this round of media warfare out, if Spotify can increase their market share of distribution proportionally to the increase of their market share of content, then they suddenly have a huge advertiser and subscriber advantage (not to mention the fact that they already have great subscriber mechanics in place, sorry Substack). For those podcast producers who were hoping that Spotify, as a distribution channel, might be the place to open up analytics due to their having a dog in the fight, that seems less likely.

Spotify makes what money it makes through two methods: adverts served to free users, and the Premium subscription fee. As with every media business, you’re better, more stable, if you can push people towards the upfront payment, rather than relying on a turbulent advertising market. Being an end-to-end point of call for podcasters isn’t worth half a billion dollars to Spotify, but it is worth something, just as continuing to diversify its audio portfolio is worth something. The tech behind Premium, which eradicates the adverts that populate the free listening experience, will presumably be applied across podcasts, offering something tangible to podcast listeners as well — I imagine a large chunk of the podcast listening market would be willing to pay $10 a month to divest all their podcast content of lengthy, obstreperous advertising. Spotify can streamline and make a feature of that; the downside will be that podcast creators using the Spotify/Anchor facilities will, again, be disincentivised (or disallowed) from making their own sponsorship deals.

I think the purchase of Gimlet is less interesting to be honest. It catches the attention because every dude in podcasting fancies himself as the next Alex Blumberg, the next guy to make a genuinely big business through nothing but woke, liberal content creation. It’s the liberal arts degree dream; to be a tech entrepreneur without being able to write a line of code. Gimlet gives Spotify credibility in this arena, and a sexy brand through which to channel their original programming. Podcast audiences have been a bit sceptical of Spotify Original content, in the same way that TV viewers have been sniffy about, say, YouTube Premium or Facebook Watch. There is something quite unnatural about these tech companies entering the content game (Amazon is the obvious exception, but even Apple has struggled). Buying Gimlet might prove to be a canny move, giving Spotify the chance to do a Netflix — as Baschez notes of Ted Sarandos’ programming regime there — with Gimlet the established, public face of this manoeuvre.

Will this be bad for podcasting? Probably. The industry has avoided the hegemony trap for a long time, for better or worse. But it seems that’s the way its going. Spotify will seek to solve the discoverability issues within podcasting, and they are well placed to do it given their membership base and almost creepy access to user data. But the more money funnelled into this project, especially in-house, the more incentive there will be for Spotify to back its horses. We’ve seen something similar on a smaller scale here in the UK, with the BBC seeming to start taking podcasting seriously, but doing all it can to close outside providers from the loop.

And, of course, there’s the fact that Spotify doesn’t really make money. If a major issue in podcasting is its failure to guarantee content providers food and shelter, then inflating the bubble with venture capital is unlikely to provide a solution. The bods at Spotify HQ obviously have a long-term profit-making plan that includes podcasting, but equally they know it’s there to augment their music streaming business. I’m not convinced that playing second fiddle in a venture capitalist’s re-imagination of the music industry is necessarily the shot in the arm that podcasting needs. Baschez predicts that Spotify will pay its content creators like YouTube does — that is, perhaps, the gloomiest prediction I’ve read all year.

The big takeaways from this deal, for me, are, i) don’t be deceived into thinking that there is money in purely content creating podcast businesses, ii) that said, now might be a REALLY GOOD time to seek investment for your content creating podcast business, iii) I think we are moving into an era of podcasting blocs, and I expect other people to act as counterweights to the Spotify bloc, iv) the path for hobbyists to go pro is only going to get harder, and I think we’ll see a further stratification so that people are either recording on a potato in their garden shed OR getting commissions from major players — to quote Yeats, the centre cannot hold, v) everything that we know or I predict about podcasting might be wrong, because all it takes is a tech-bro wrecking ball to shake up an entire industry, as Spotify has done this week. I have no idea what’s coming next and I slightly dread finding out.

You can follow me on Twitter if you are a masochist.
